p: E protein of coronavirus is a short polypeptide integral membrane protein that has been involved with different steps of the life cycle of the virus, such as assembly, budding, envelope formation, and pathogenesis (Masters, 2006). It has been reported that the absence or inactivation of E protein could impact either virion morphology or tropism (Khattari et al., 2006; Pervushin et al., 2009). E proteins of coronaviruses have shown cation‐selective ion channel activity and thus have membrane permeabilizing property (Wilson, McKinlay, Gage, & Ewart, 2004). SARS‐CoVs lacking E protein show lower viral titer, immature, and inefficient progenies (Kuo, Hurst, & Masters, 2007), thereby recommending E protein a suitable drug target to prevent viral replication and infection.
